question: Question_04_(a)
sols:
Set the following change of variable

\begin{align*}u = \sqrt{x}\end{align*} then we have

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{ x = u^2 }\end{align*} and so

\begin{align*}\displaystyle{ dx = 2u \, du }.\end{align*} Making this substitution in the
integral gives

\begin{align*}\int \frac{\sqrt{x}}{x-1} dx 
= \int \frac{u}{u^2 - 1} \, 2u \, du 
= 2\int \frac{u^2}{u^2 - 1} du.\end{align*}

Now we use the method of partial fractions. We have

\begin{align*}
\int \frac{\sqrt{x}}{x-1} dx 
&=2 \int \frac{u^2}{u^2 - 1} du \\
&= 2 \int \frac{u^2 - 1 + 1}{u^2 - 1} du \\
&= 2\int \left( 1 + \frac{1}{u^2 - 1} \right) du \\
&= 2u + \int \frac{2}{u^2 - 1} du \\
&= u + \int \frac{2}{(u - 1)(u+1)} du.\end{align*}

We want to find numbers $A$ and $B$ such that

\begin{align*}\frac{2}{(u - 1)(u+1)} = \frac{A}{u-1} + \frac{B}{u+1}.\end{align*}

Multiplying both sides by $(u-1)(u+1)$ yields

\begin{align*}\displaystyle 2 = Au + A + Bu - B.\end{align*}

Equating coefficients of powers of $u$ on both sides gives

\begin{align*}\begin{cases} 0 = A + B\\
2 = A - B \end{cases}\end{align*}

From the first of these equations we see that $A = - B$. So the second
equation becomes

\begin{align*}\displaystyle
2 = 2A.\end{align*} Hence $A = 1$ and $B = -A = -1$. Therefore, we have

\begin{align*}\frac{2}{(u - 1)(u+1)} = \frac{1}{u-1} - \frac{1}{u+1}.\end{align*}

Using this to rewrite the last integral above, we find

\begin{align*}
\int \frac{\sqrt{x}}{x-1} dx 
&= 2u + \int \frac{2}{(u - 1)(u+1)} du \\
&= 2u + \int \frac{1}{u-1} du -  \int \frac{1}{u+1} du \\
&= 2u + \ln|u-1| - \ln|u+1| + C \\
&= 2\sqrt{x} + \ln|\sqrt{x}-1| - \ln|\sqrt{x}+1| + C.\end{align*}
